oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery interviews Kathy Mattea and the Wright Brothers Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Kathy Mattea (performer) and the Wright Brothers (performance group) for the Ralph Emery Show. Tape labeled parts 1, 2 and 3. Recording is from an unknown date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Kathy Mattea; Wright Brothers
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Kathy Mattea and the Wright brothers radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:15) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery introduction voiceover] -- (00:40) Emery invites the audience to meet Mattea and the Wright Brothers -- (01:50) Mattea discusses how "Street Talk" was mistaken for Terry Gibbs, and Emery invites Mattea to reflect on the difficulty associated with Mattea's last name -- (04:09) Emery recalls first meeting the Wright Brothers when they released "Family Man" and performed on Nashville Alive -- (06:19) Emery introduces the Wright Brothers, and invites them to discuss how John McDowell became a member of the Wright Brothers -- (08:39) Emery introduces Moe Bandy and Joe Stampley's "The Boy's Night Out" -- (09:15) Emery praises Mattea, and addresses how she was a guide at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum -- (13:38) Emery invites Mattea to discuss "That's Easy For You to Say" -- (14:46) Emery discusses the stars of tomorrow segment the Ralph Emery Show does, and Tom Wright expresses his happiness with "So Close" -- (16:32) Emery discusses Mattea's album cover while introducing "Full Time Love" -- (17:21) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery, Mattea, and the Wright Brothers outro voiceover] -- (18:35) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery, Mattea, and the Wright Brothers introduction voiceover] -- (19:07) Emery has McDowell introduce Janie Fricke's "Your Hearts Not in It" -- (19:40) Emery inquires who are the Cough Drop Brothers, and the Wright brothers recall the Smiths while introducing "Southern Women" -- (23:02) Emery invites McDowell to discuss how his father was a employee of K-Mart -- (25:20) Mattea describes how she was introduced to "Someone is Falling in Love" -- (26:20) Mattea praises Ricky Skaggs while introducing "Uncle Pen" -- (27:17) Emery reveals he is a fan of basketball and Larry Bird; additionally, the Wright Brothers discuss how they went to the same high school as Bird -- (30:00) "When You Find Her, Keep Her" and the Wright Brothers' relationship with Warner Brothers is discussed -- (32:18) Emery inquires about Mattea's hometown, and both discuss Mattea's work in Nashville to promote her career -- (35:25) Tom Wright and the Wright Brothers discuss the friendly atmosphere of Nashville -- (37:08) Tim Wright introduces "Easy Street" -- (37:54) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery, Mattea, and the Wright Brothers outro voiceover] -- (39:09) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery, Mattea, and the Wright Brothers introduction voiceover] -- (39:28) Emery and Mattea discuss Mattea's easily-embarrassed nature -- (40:13) Emery pokes at Tom Wright, and Tom is asked to introduce "Give Me One More Chance" -- (41:18) "Back to the Heartbreak Kid" is told by Mattea to be a song she may name her band after -- (42:56) Emery inquires about Mattea's Italian roots -- (45:07) Emery inquires about a disgusting story from Tim Wright, but interrupts Tim to have him introduce "Eight Days a Week" -- (47:16) Emery reintroduces Tim Wright to tell his disgusting story -- (50:54) Emery has Mattea introduce "That's Easy For You to Say" after asking her if she knew what nunchucks are -- (51:27) Emery invokes the memory of Mattea being the voice behind a Nashville Camber of Commerce commercial -- (51:58) All Roads Lead to Nashville (Mattea) -- (52:35) Mattea reveals that the commercial shot for the Nashville Chamber of Commerce featured a lip singing actress; additionally, Emery inquires how Mattea got the opportunity -- (54:39) Emery inquires about the number of records, of the Wright Brothers, McDowell had been featured on -- (55:30) Emery has Mattea introduce Ray Charles' "Rock and Roll Shoes" -- (56:12) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery, Mattea, and the Wright Brothers outro voiceover]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Mattea, Kathy; the Wright Brothers Band (Musical group);
